instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN: What is EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN? EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN is necessary to enable the power rail that powers the LCD screen image circuitry. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No internal video / external video works / system boots and operates perfectly otherwise / dead <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL> channel
threads.message:
Hey folks!

This is mostly a double-check before I call something prematurely.

System is fully functional except for its internal display which has no image / no backlight.  Both.

<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is at 0V.  All supplies to <CHIP>U8500</CHIP>, <CHIP>U8501</CHIP>, and <CHIP>U8510</CHIP> are present.  

So either that signal is being shorted to ground by <CHIP>U8510</CHIP> - OR - after reading other posts it seems like the system may simply not be able to detect the internal display because I have 0.172V for all <SIGNAL>EDP_INT</SIGNAL> lines EXCEPT <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL>, which reads 0.001V.

From [URL='https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-no-internal-video.62246/post-85930']this response by the great 2informaticos[/URL] I see someone with similar diode mode readings on a 2017 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, where with that low diode mode reading on <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL>, he calls time of death, saying that the CPU's eDP output is damaged because there are no series capacitors to protect data lines on that board, which is also the case on this one.

That's all there is to it, right? This is a desktop with a battery backup now?

Again, I'm pretty sure that that's all the case and I SUPER value your time, but I figure I owe my customer to double check in the interest of due diligence before failing to resolve something obvious, or offering a silly workaround for the customer if one might exist.

I threw in as many keywords as I could so others can save everyone's time by not asking this in the future, eeeven just to double-check like me.  ;)  Hope that makes up for the potentially silly inquiry.

Thank you so much for your time!

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No internal video / external video works / system boots and operates perfectly otherwise / dead <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL> channel
threads.message:
While I'm at it, any explanation for how that could happen to a completely untouched, no liquid exposure board would be awesome.  Besides the design flaw of a lack of a coupling cap to block DC from getting in there, that is.  

It really just has to have been some transient moisture or something that... maybe bridged the 3.3V line into the CPU across the <RESISTOR>R8503</RESISTOR> nostuff gap one, but then left no corrosion or residue to suggest such a thing?  Or a manufacturing defect in the CPU?

Wild speculation is wholly welcome.  ;)

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No internal video / external video works / system boots and operates perfectly otherwise / dead <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL> channel
threads.message:
That line is also near the backlight voltage on the T-CON board; placed on LCD assembly.
So the leakage could happened there.

Any case, disconnect J8500 and check again diode mode to ground.
If still short, no doubt internal video is lost forever; unless change the CPU, of course.

threads.title: 2016 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No internal video / external video works / system boots and operates perfectly otherwise / dead <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL> channel
threads.message:
Oh yeah, hah, yep!  That IS the backlight line right there, isn't it.   SIGH.

Thanks so much, man.  I really appreciate you weighing in with the conclusivity!
